notificatie.titel: UK variant gains terrain in the Netherlands
notificatie.bericht: The number of newly tested COVID positives slightly decreased to 35.635 cases in the week of 20 to 26 January compared to the week before. This overview is overshadowed by the rising number of cases involving the SARS-CoV-2 variant that resulted in a massive influx of patients in hospitals in the United Kingdom and Ireland. It is estimated that the people that got infected with COVID-19 in the past week (20 to 26 January), more than a third is infected with the UK variant. We are facing two variants of the virus that seem to be spreading in the Netherlands at different speeds. As a result, there are essentially two separate COVID-19 epidemics: one epidemic involving the ‘old’ variant, in which infections are decreasing, and another epidemic involving the UK variant, in which infections are increasing.

ic_opnames_per_dag.titel: Reported intensive care admissions by day
ic_opnames_per_dag.pagina_toelichting: Daily number of COVID-19 patients admitted to a hospital intensive care unit (ICU), directly or from a regular hospital ward. To avoid doubles only the first IC admission of a patient counts. This number gives information about the severity of the disease en helps track the development of the epidemic.

ic_opnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg:
Number of confirmed COVID-19 cases who are admitted to a hospital intensive care unit (ICU) per day. This figure shows how many hospital admissions are reported per day. It may include hospital admissions that occurred in previous days.

Note: From 25 March, the dashboard will show the number of reported IC admissions per day instead of the average number of admissions over the past three days. The number above is therefore not comparable with the number that was previously on the dashboard.

chart_bedbezetting.title: ICU bed occupancy over time
chart_bedbezetting.description: This graph shows the number of ICU beds occupied over time by patients with COVID-19. It represents not just the days on which patients were admitted to hospital but all days on which patients with COVID-19 were in hospital.

This section of the dashboard shows the number of patients with COVID-19 admitted to hospital each day and the number of regular hospital beds occupied by patients with COVID-19. The dashboard provides national and regional figures drawn from various sources.
ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg: Number of people with COVID-19 admitted to hospital daily. This figure shows how many hospital admissions are reported per day, including patients from outside the hospital admitted directly to the ICU. It may include hospital admissions that occurred in previous days.

ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_toelichting: This map shows, by municipality or safety region, where people live who have been admitted to hospital with COVID-19. Please note that people may have been admitted to a hospital located somewhere else in the Netherlands; the map therefore does not show admission numbers per hospital. The figures here reflect the daily hospital admissions reported to the National Intensive Care Evaluation Registry (Stichting NICE).

besmettelijke_personen.title: Number of infectious people
besmettelijke_personen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a weekly basis.
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_line: The number of infectious people in the Netherlands.
besmettelijke_personen.legenda_marge: The number of infectious people is an estimate. The uncertainty margin indicates how much higher or lower the actual number may be.
besmettelijke_personen.geen_signaalwaarde_beschikbaar: Due to a technical problem the data is currently not showing as intended. This is being investigated.
besmettelijke_personen.toelichting_pagina: A person who carries coronavirus can infect other people within a certain time frame. If more people are infectious the virus spreads faster. It is not possible to know exactly how many people are infectious, but we can indicate whether there are dozens, hundreds, thousands or even more.

besmettelijke_personen.cijfer_titel: Number of infectious people in the Netherlands:
besmettelijke_personen.cijfer_toelichting: A calculation of how many people with COVID-19 can transmit the virus. This number is always a week or to old because more recent calculations are not accurate enough.

reproductiegetal.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated twice per week.
reproductiegetal.legenda_r: The reproduction number is not an exact value but a reliable estimate. Reproduction numbers (R) using data from less than two weeks ago are not reliable, therefore, the line depicting R stops at a date two weeks in the past.
reproductiegetal.legenda_marge: The confidence interval shows the range between which the number R falls. This is updated twice per week.
reproductiegetal.reproductie_explainer_alt: Image to support the explanation above
reproductiegetal.pagina_toelichting: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. The number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with COVID-19.
reproductiegetal.barscale_toelichting: Number of people infected by one infectious person. This number is always two weeks old, since more current calculations are to unreliable.
reproductiegetal.extra_uitleg: The reproduction number shows how fast the virus is spreading. This number shows how many people are on average infected by one patient with COVID-19. The number of transmissions remains more or less constant when the reproduction number is 1, declines when it is less than 1 and increases when the number is above 1.

overige_gegevens.title: To be developed
overige_gegevens.text: We aim to expand the dashboard in the future with the following data:

list.content:
The RIVM monitors the spread of infectious diseases in many ways. This is also the case for COVID-19. One of these ways is to look at persons exhibiting symptoms that could indicate an infection. The RIVM does this with the Infectieradar.

Everyone in the Netherlands can take part in the Infectieradar. Participants self-report once a week if they have (had) a fever or other symptoms. Even if participants don't have any symptoms they pass this on to us. This way, signals of an increase or decrease in the spread of the virus are picked up earlier.

list.text: Contact tracing by the municipal public health service (GGD)
list.content: When someone is infected with COVID-19, the municipal health service (GGD) tries to find out where they got it from and who they recently had contact with. The purpose is to discover whether the virus has also been transmitted to any other people.

Care professionals with COVID-19 can infect their patients, so monitoring care professionals’ health can help contain the spread of the disease. This means keeping track of the number of care professionals who are infected with coronavirus and the number who report ill. This data also helps the healthcare system cope with increases in workload.
Data on the movement of people can indicate how the coronavirus is spreading. The aim is to show this per municipality.
The compliance monitor provides insight into the degree to which people are able to follow the coronavirus measures.

RIVM routinely collects data from behavioural studies that shed light on trends in compliance with and support for the basic rules that apply, like washing hands, staying home and getting tested if you have symptoms.

rioolwater_metingen.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
rioolwater_metingen.pagina_toelichting: If you are infected with coronavirus, there are likely to be virus particles in your stool. These are flushed down the toilet and end up in wastewater. By testing samples of wastewater collected at wastewater treatment plants, we can get information about how widespread the virus is in the community. Please note: As of 4 March, more refined data analytics are being used. This leads to different values.
rioolwater_metingen.barscale_titel: Average number of virus particles per 100,000 inhabitants
rioolwater_metingen.extra_uitleg: The calculated average is based on all the wastewater measurements collected in one week. This figure also takes account of how many inhabitants are served by a wastewater treatment plant.
rioolwater_metingen.linechart_titel: Average number of virus particles over time (per 100,000 inhabitants)

[Read more about this research programme on the website of the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM)](https://www.rivm.nl/coronavirus-covid-19/onderzoek/rioolwater).

veiligheidsregio_rioolwater_metingen.pagina_toelichting: If you are infected with coronavirus, there are likely to be virus particles in your stool. By testing samples of wastewater collected at wastewater treatment plants, we can get information about how widespread the virus is in the community. Please note: As of 4 March, more refined data analytics are being used. This leads to different values.

gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.titel: Reported hospital admissions per day of residents in {{municipality}}
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.pagina_toelichting: A rise in the number of patients with COVID-19 could overburden hospitals. This number is also a valid indicator for epidemic growth. This section of the dashboard shows the number of patients with COVID-19 admitted to hospital each day and the number of regular hospital beds occupied by patients with COVID-19. The dashboard provides national and regional figures drawn from various sources.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.datums: Calculated: {{dateOfReport}}. Is updated on a daily basis.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.extra_uitleg: Number of people from this municipality with COVID-19 admitted to hospital on a daily basis. This figure shows how many hospital admissions are reported per day, including patients from outside the hosptial admitted directly to the ICU. Patients can be admitted to hospitals in other regions.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_titel: Distribution of hospital admissions in safety region of {{municipality}}
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.map_toelichting: This map shows, by municipality or safety region, where people live who have been admitted to hospital with COVID-19. Please note that people may have been admitted to a hospital located somewhere else in the Netherlands; the map therefore does not show admission numbers per hospital. The figures here reflect the daily hospital admissions reported to the National Intensive Care Evaluation Registry (Stichting NICE).
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_titel: Hospital admissions over time, by admission date
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.barscale_screenreader_text: {{value}} hospital admissions per day. Alert value: {{signaalwaarde}} admissions per day.
gemeente_ziekenhuisopnames_per_dag.linechart_description: This graph shows hospital admissions, including admissions directly to ICU. The figure for each day indicates the number of people actually admitted on that day, not the number of admissions reported on that day. This gives a clear picture of the development of coronavirus in the Netherlands. There are often reporting delays of a few days for hospital admissions; data for the most recent days is therefore incomplete. The graph also shows an average of the number of hospital admissions over the past seven days.

escalatie_niveau.toelichting: Every two weeks the coronavirus situation is assessed to see whether it is developing in a positive or negative direction, most recently on {{last_update}}. The risk level in a particular region is based on the number of positive tests and the number of hospital admissions. [More information about the risk levels](/over-risiconiveaus).

1.toelichting: The situation is manageable. The number of new confirmed cases is low. There is sufficient healthcare capacity

2.toelichting: The situation is becoming difficult to manage. There are many new confirmed cases. Pressure on healthcare capacity is increasing.

3.toelichting: The situation is serious. The number of new confirmed cases is large. Pressure on healthcare capacity is very high.

4.toelichting: The situation is severe. The number of new confirmed cases is extremely high. Pressure on healthcare capacity is extreme.

This means that the total number of people who have tested positive differs from the number of people who have tested positive at GGD test locations.

metadata.title: Compliance and support | Coronavirus Dashboard | Government.nl
metadata.description: National overview of compliance and support

pagina.toelichting: The Netherlands’ approach is essentially to control the virus as much as possible, avoid overburdening the healthcare system and protect vulnerable groups. We can get coronavirus under control, but only if we all follow the basic rules.

nl_gedrag.datums: This survey was carried out between {{weekStart}} and {{weekEnd}}. Is updated every 3 weeks.

onderzoek_uitleg.toelichting: Every three weeks a survey of a representative sample of the Dutch population is carried out. Survey respondents all answer the same questions about the basic rules that the government has laid down to combat coronavirus. The purpose of the survey is to find out to what extent the public supports and follows these rules. The survey is coordinated and published by RIVM, and carried out by Kantar Public.

verdeling_in_nederland.intro: Select a basic rule to see the differences between safety regions.

voetnoot.compliance: This table shows the percentage of survey respondents who reported following each of the basic rules in their daily life.
voetnoot.support: This table shows the percentage of survey respondents who reported supporting each of the basic rules.

voetnoot_asterisk.compliance: * Any difference compared to the previous measurement can be shown with 95% certainty.
voetnoot_asterisk.support: * Any difference compared to the previous measurement can be shown with 95% certainty.

basisregels_over_tijd.title: Following the rules of conduct over time over time

intro.compliance: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported following the basic rule in their daily life.
intro.support: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported supporting the basic rule.

voetnoot.support: This table shows the percentage of survey respondents who reported supporting each of the basic rules.

intro.compliance: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported following the basic rule in their daily life.
intro.support: This graph shows the changes in the percentage of respondents who reported supporting the basic rule.

infected_age_groups.title: Distribution by age
infected_age_groups.description: The blue (right) bars in this graph show which age group positive tested persons belong to. The gray (left) bars show how large each age group is in relation to the entire Dutch population. The blue and gray bars together show whether age groups have relatively more or less positive tested persons. For example: 16% of all positive tested persons are in their twenties (blue bar) and 13% of all Dutch people are in their twenties (gray bar). In this example, the age group twenties has relatively more positive tested people. The chart is updated daily and covers only the most recently reported cases.
infected_age_groups.example: For example: of all positive tested people is {{infectedPercentage}} between {{ageGroupRange}} years old. Of all Dutch people is {{ageGroupPercentage}} between {{ageGroupRange}} years old.

section_sterftemonitor.title: Mortality monitor
section_sterftemonitor.description: Every week the national office Statistics Netherlands (CBS) publishes data on the total number of deaths and compares this to the predicted number of deaths, corrected for extreme temperatures, epidemics, etc. If more deaths occur than predicted, these are considered excess deaths. This graph may show a more complete picture of COVID-19 related deaths than the numbers reported by the GGD because not everyone who dies from COVID-19 has been tested for it.
section_sterftemonitor.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.

cbs.download: https://opendata.cbs.nl/ODataApi/odata/70895ned/TypedDataSet?$filter=((Geslacht eq '1100')) and ((LeeftijdOp31December eq '10000')) and (substringof('W', Perioden) eq true)&$select=Perioden, Overledenen_1

reference.text: To find out more about the information on this page, go to ‘Explanation of the data presented’.

cbs_message.title: Excess mortality among people under 80 in week 15
cbs_message.message: In week 15 (12 to 18 April inclusive), the estimated number of deaths stood at slightly less than 3,200. This is nearly 200 more than expected for this period and slightly more than in the previous week (3,132). Mortality was higher than expected among people aged 65 to 79 in particular. There was also excess mortality was among people under 65. Mortality among long-term care users was again below the expected level. Statistics Netherlands (CBS) reports this based on the provisional weekly mortality figures. From week 39 of 2020 to week 6 of 2021, weekly mortality was higher than expected. There was excess mortality until week 3. In the following weeks, mortality was not elevated and fluctuated around the expected numbers for that period. The estimate for week 15 is almost 200 deaths above the expected number, but is still just within the range of usual fluctuations (and is therefore not classified as excess mortality). The National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) registered 126 COVID-19 deaths in week 15 (as at 20 April).

link.text: Read the full news item on the CBS website

section_sterftemonitor.deceased_monitor_chart_title: Total number of deaths per week
section_sterftemonitor.deceased_monitor_chart_description: This graph shows the total number of deaths per week. The actual number of deaths is compared to the number of deaths predicted based on the figures from preceding years. The light blue line, drawn within its range of uncertainty, shows the number of deaths predicted over the year. The dark blue line shows the number of actual deaths.

grafieken.verwachte_leveringen:
The left-hand side of the graph shows how many vaccine doses in total were available in the Netherlands and how many doses have been administered. The right-hand side of the graph shows how many vaccine doses we will have available in the coming weeks and how many doses are to be administered in the coming weeks.

The graph only contains the vaccines for the European Netherlands. The calculation is based on a waste of 1%.
grafieken.vaccin_levering_en_prikken:
The left-hand side of the graph shows how many vaccine doses in total were available in the Netherlands and how many doses have been administered. The right-hand side of the graph shows how many vaccine doses we will have available in the coming weeks and how many doses are to be administered in the coming weeks. Until March 23, the chart also included deliveries for the Caribbean. As of 23 March, we only show vaccines for the European Netherlands in the entire graph.

The calculation is based on a waste of 1%.
grafieken.vaccinatie_draagvlak: This graph shows the percentage of the population that wishes to be vaccinated against COVID-19.

deceased_age_groups.title: COVID-19 deaths by age
deceased_age_groups.description: The blue bars on the right of this graph show the age distribution of people who have died with COVID 19. The grey bars on the left show how large each age group is in relation to the entire Dutch population. Taken together, the blue and grey bars show whether there are proportionately more or fewer COVID-19 deaths in each age group. If, for example, the graph shows that people in their sixties represent 12% of the Dutch population (grey bar) and that this same group represents 10% of the people in the Netherlands who have died with COVID-19 (blue bar), that means there are proportionately fewer deaths with COVID-19 among people in their sixties. The graph is updated daily and includes all deaths since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. Please note that RIVM groups COVID-19 deaths among people younger than 50 together; the low numbers could otherwise be traceable back to individual people.

vaccinaties.title: COVID-19 vaccinations
vaccinaties.description: Vaccination is the most important step towards getting life back to normal. The Netherlands began vaccinating people against COVID-19 on 6 January 2021. Eventually, the vaccine will be offered to everyone aged 18 and over. This page shows how many doses of vaccine have been administered and how many doses are on their way.

grafiek.titel: Delivered and checked doses & doses administered in total
grafiek.omschrijving:
The left-hand side of the graph shows how many vaccine doses in total were available in the Netherlands and how many doses have been administered. The right-hand side of the graph shows how many vaccine doses we will have available in the coming weeks and how many doses are to be administered in the coming weeks. Until March 23, the chart also included deliveries for the Caribbean. As of 23 March, we only show vaccines for the European Netherlands in the entire graph.

The calculation is based on a waste of 1%.

grafiek_draagvlak.omschrijving: This graph shows the percentage per age group and in total of the population that wishes to be vaccinated against COVID-19. The figures are taken from a survey where people are asked if they wish to be vaccinated. The survey is conducted every three weeks.

grafiek_gezette_prikken.omschrijving: This graph shows the total number of doses administered according to calculations.

kpi_geplande_prikken_deze_week.omschrijving: Number of doses the Netherlands expects to administer from {{date_from}} to {{date_to}}. The actual number may differ, for example due to people cancelling their appointments or problems with vaccine deliveries.

clock.title: One person is vaccinated every {{seconds}} seconds
clock.description: This is an estimate. The estimated figure is based on an average of {{amount}} doses per day between 08.00 and 20.00 over the past seven days.

bereidheid_section.title: Willingness to be vaccinated
bereidheid_section.description: Coronavirus vaccination is not obligatory. But if everyone does get vaccinated, the virus will no longer be able to spread. It is therefore vital to know how many people are prepared to be vaccinated. Every three weeks, the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) conducts a survey to establish how many people want to be vaccinated.

reference.text: To find out more about the information on this page, go to ‘Explanation of the data presented’.

stock_and_delivery_section.title: Deliveries and stock
stock_and_delivery_section.description: How many vaccine doses can be administered depends on how many doses we receive. Vaccine doses are delivered to the Netherlands every week. After quality control the majority of these are available for vaccination. We keep some doses in a safely stock to ensure enough vaccine doses for both appointments the first few days and the second dose. This page shows how many doses of vaccine were delivered to the Netherlands and how many doses are in stock.

reference.text: To find out more about the information on this page, go to ‘Explanation of the data presented’.

stock.title: Doses in stock
stock.description: This is the number of vaccine doses currently in stock at the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM) per vaccine type. We are not holding aside any more vaccine than is necessary to make sure everyone can receive a second dose on time.

delivery_estimate_time_span.title: Doses to be delivered
delivery_estimate_time_span.description: This is the number of vaccine doses the Netherlands expects to receive over the next four weeks. The Netherlands will receive a new delivery each week. People need two separately administered doses for the vaccine to be maximally effective, except for the Janssen vaccine. One dose of the Janssen vaccine is enough.

grafiek_leveringen.omschrijving: This graph shows how many doses of each vaccine the Netherlands has received or expects to receive in a given week. It assumes 6 doses per vaccine vial for BioNTech / Pfizer, 10 doses per vaccine vial for Moderna, 11 doses per vaccine vial for AstraZeneca and 5 doses per vaccine vial for Janssen.

vaccinaties.bereidheid_datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated every three weeks.

stock_per_supplier_chart.title: Doses in stock per type of vaccine
stock_per_supplier_chart.description: This is the number of vaccine doses currently in stock at the National Institute for Public Health and the Environment (RIVM). The total stock consists of the available and not yet available stock. The available stock is ready for use and partly consists of safety stock. Stocks that are not yet available are vaccines in quality control. After quality control the vaccines are available.

legend.total: Total number of doses in stock of {{vaccineName}} vaccine

kpi_vaccinatiegraad.omschrijving: Percentage mensen in Nederland dat **volledig** gevaccineerd is ten opzicht van alle mensen in Nederland die voor vaccinatie in aanmerking komen.

grafiek_gevaccineerde_mensen.omschrijving: Deze grafiek laat zien hoeveel mensen in Nederland een prik hebben gehad en hoeveel mensen daarvan volledig en gedeeltelijk gevaccineerd zijn. Met de huidige vaccinatieplan verwachten we dat ieder persoon die in Nederland wil zich laten vaccineren zou bij eind juli 2021 een eerste prik mogen krijgen.

vr_risiconiveau.pagina_toelichting: Every 2 weeks we reassess the risk level in each safety region based on the number of positive tests (new confirmed cases) and the number of hospital admissions there. If one of these figures gives cause to set a higher risk level than the other, the higher risk level applies. Certain measures apply at each risk level. The exact measures that apply in this safety region depend on the situation in the rest of the country as well as the situation here.

header.title: Use of the CoronaMelder app
header.description: The CoronaMelder app has been developed to help fight the spread of coronavirus. The app keeps track of when users have been within close range of one another for a longer period of time. If a CoronaMelder user tests positive for COVID-19, they can choose to alert other app users. App users who get an alert can then get tested and avoid unknowingly infecting others.
header.datums: Last values obtained on {{dateOfInsertion}}. Is updated on a daily basis.

reference.text: To find out more about the information on this page, go to ‘Explanation of the data presented’.

waarschuwingen.description: This figure shows how many CoronaMelder users who tested positive alerted other app users of this yesterday.

rapport.title: Factsheet CoronaMelder
rapport.description: Researchers are closely monitoring the CoronaMelder app’s impact. Read the most recent factsheet about this on the CoronaMelder website.

waarschuwingen_over_tijd_grafiek.title: Warnings over time
waarschuwingen_over_tijd_grafiek.description: This graph shows how many users with a confirmed case of COVID-19 have informed other users of CoronaMelder of this.

section_sterftemonitor_vr.title: Mortality monitor
section_sterftemonitor_vr.description: Every week the national office Statistics Netherlands (CBS) publishes data on the total number of deaths and compares this to the predicted number of deaths, corrected for extreme temperatures, epidemics, etc. If more deaths occur than predicted, these are considered excess deaths. This graph may show a more complete picture of COVID-19 related deaths than the numbers reported by the GGD because not everyone who dies from COVID-19 has been tested for it.

reference.text: Read more about the information on this page in the 'Explanation of data presented'.

infected_per_age_group.title: Number of positive tests per age group over time
infected_per_age_group.description: This graph shows the number of people per 100,000 who have tested positive for coronavirus, by age group. It uses averages from the previous seven days. Please note that the figures here may vary from the number of confirmed cases shown elsewhere on this page. That is because they are based on different data sets. The data set on which this graph is based uses, in most cases, the first day of illness. Read more about this in the explanation of data presented.

infected_per_age_group.line_chart_legend_inaccurate_label: Data for recent days is incomplete due to reporting delays

bar_chart.title: Trend in daily positive tests (Growth rate)
bar_chart.description: The Growth rate (or G rate) shows how the number of daily positive tests over the last 7 days has developed relative to the previous 7 days. A positive Growth rate indicates a rising trend in the number of positive tests. A negative Growth rate indicates a declining trend in the number of positive tests. The graph shows the Growth rate of the last five weeks.
